abstract.p: The article models the upset—a low-probability outcome of a periodic competition. It is assumed that the upset is an independent component of consumer preferences, whose marginal willingness to pay grows with time. The decision rule for a league on upset timing is a competitive-balance problem but is unlike standard models of competitive balance. Upset timing is likened partially to the optimal redemption time of a growing asset, and implications for competitive balance in this environment are derived.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: What exactly is it that makes for-profit sports attractive to those who pay to consume it? As with any emerging field, sports economics began by making very simple assumptions—that demand is about the success of one’s own team and overall competitive balance in particular. But, when one looks at what is written popularly about sports, this seems to be a somewhat narrow conception of what makes them appealing. In fact, much of the drama of sports involves events before and after the competition, as well as enjoyment (or distress) from results that have little to do with a permanent rooting interest in a particular team. While in recent years there has been progress in analyzing these other, perhaps once-removed aspects of demand, much remains to be done. Indeed, Mason (1999, p. 405) argues that the primary feature of fan demand is that it is “enhanced by association to a specific team or its competitors.”

This article explores one such aspect—the upset. Without question, fans often take great pleasure when highly favored teams lose games, especially important games. This is true even when the loss does not affect fans' own teams' place in the standings. Instead, the low-probability outcome seems to generate excitement in its own right. From the point of view of a sports league trying to decide how frequently upsets should happen, this problem bears some resemblance to optimal asset harvesting—the decision of when to redeem an asset that is more productive the longer the owner can wait, even while waiting requires that income be deferred and other options be foregone. Thinking this way, the optimal time to upset can be modeled based on the classic tree-harvesting problem solved by Hirshleifer (1970) and Samuelson (1976), combined with a Szymanski (2001) model of fandom. This article models the upset as a problem of expected asset maturation. Section The Upset sets up the basic framework, the Section Equilibria compares two outcomes, when the league and individual teams decide on team talent, and the Section League Responses shows how leagues can induce teams to take account of upset revenue and the corresponding effects on competitive balance.

sec.title: The Upset
sec.p: The standard model of sports leagues, summarized in Vrooman (2009) and Fort and Quirk (1995), is based on optimal winning percentages, derived from differing market sizes, in combination with decentralized decision making—teams, in other words, and not leagues choose talent. But, equilibrium winning percentages can also be thought of as expected length to victory by the less-favored team, which in turn resembles the theory of optimal asset maturity. In the aforementioned tree problem, the farmer must choose when to harvest the asset, knowing that deferring harvest will postpone income and incur additional maintenance costs but also increase revenue once the tree is harvested (because waiting yields more lumber). The expected timing of a sports upset does differ from the classical tree problem in two critical respects. The first is that the alternative to the upset is also a revenue-generating event, namely the favored team continuing to win. The second is that for there to be demand for competition there must be uncertainty. Unless the modeling choice is to assume game outcomes are known to the league but invisible to fans, the upset must be a stochastic process, as indeed games must be generally. Thus, while a tree is cut down at a date certain, upset timing can only be expressed in expected terms. The solution is a life expectancy rather than a lifespan. This provides a key link to much of the standard model of game outcomes.

Begin with the standard Fort and Quirk (1995) model, itself descended from El-Hodiri and Quirk (1971). The model is a simple closed-talent one with two teams, and all parties risk-neutral. Each team has a talent level Si , and the difference in team-winning percentages is a function of the talent possessed by each team. In that article, committed fans, one set for each team, care about their team winning. Uncommitted ones are indifferent to the final score and care only about suspense. Implicitly, in expectation, those upsets that are most valued are those that occur the least frequently, because greater skill differentials translate into longer expected streaks. The upset is wine and not beer—the longer the streak ages, the greater the appeal to uncommitted fans when it finally (in expectation) does, and the more they are willing to pay for each (stochastically determined) occurrence of it.

sec.title: Equilibria
sec.p: Two equilibria are compared, one that maximizes league profits when the league selects talent levels and one that occurs when the teams do. While the default model of leagues frequently assumes teams as decision-makers, in many areas of team-sports analysis (e.g., U.S. college athletics or franchise location), monopolistic or cartel behavior is often assumed. Thus, both outcomes are compared.

The league thus faces a trade-off not just between revenue sources in different markets but within the payoff to the upset itself. On the one hand, increasing talent equality makes the upset happen more frequently, but on the other, the overall willingness to pay for the upset per occurrence is lower the more frequently it happens, as in the classic tree problem.

The added finding of interest here is that, because upset income comes from uncommitted fans, teams ignore it, assuming they see none of that income (if, for example, it is retained as rent by league management).

Compared to the standard model, whether there is more or less competitive balance depends on the importance of the upset in league calculations. In particular, two elasticities defined around talent disparity, those of demand by uncommitted fans for the upset and of upset frequency with respect to talent disparity, determine the comparative equality of talent allocation. In particular, if the former figure is small and the latter large, the league would prefer more competitive balance relative to the Nash equilibrium, because the profit-maximizing outcome is to earn smaller amounts of upset income more frequently. If the latter, then the league would actually prefer less-competitive balance because rarer doses of larger upset payoffs increase profits.

sec.p: By construction, teams ignore upset income, but it is possible for a league to design the distribution of upset income to achieve the first-best result. The key issue is again the relative size of two effects: the elasticity of wage income with response to talent disparity (i.e., how much uncommitted fans will pay, and be willing to increase the rate at which they pay, for upsets as the magnitude of the upsets increases), and the sensitivity of the probability of an upset to the size of the talent disparity. This same disparity determines equilibrium competitive balance with upset income compared to the standard case. The greater is the response of willingness to pay to increased talent disparity when an upset happens, the greater is equilibrium competitive imbalance, and the longer the expected life span of the favorite’s winning streak.

While the direction of the gap depends on the two elasticities, there is some economic intuition in assuming that the wage effect dominates, that upsets are sweeter when they are less frequent. A game in a series in which an upset happens 48 times in every 100 games played is likely to generate little ex ante interest from uncommitted fans, while one that happens once in every 20 years generates more. (One that happens once in every 1,000 years may be so improbable that the uncommitted fan expects never to see it, which would place an upper bound on the optimal amount of talent, based on upset-derived income, that should go to Team 1.)

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Assuming this characterization of the relative value of upset frequency and upset degree is correct, the model thus provides some suggestion for why competitive imbalance might be higher from the point of view of the uncommitted fan than a default analysis might suggest—for example, the so-called optimal result of each game’s outcome being 50% (Quirk & Fort, 1992). The two standard answers to this problem are to invoke the idea that bigger markets should win more owing to enhanced consumer surplus, or the (usually vaguely defined) notion of the value to fans of “dynasties”—of streams of victories by the same team (Krautmann & Hadley, 2006; Vrooman, 2009). Here, it is deferral of victory by the underdog that is of value—the source of less-competitive balance is not just market size, and not ad hoc preferences for victory streaks, but of optimal asset maturity.

The objective function of sports fans is still significantly unexplored, although demand for suspense is a long-studied problem (Chan, Courty, & Li, 2009; Forrest, Simmons, & Buraimo, 2005; Knowles, Sherony, & Haupert, 1992; Lee & Fort, 2008), and the complementarity between sports and other nonsports goods demand has also been explored (Falter, Perignon, & Vercruysse, 2008). The model developed here can perhaps be thought of as an example of a more general theory of the utility of witnessing the improbable. Such a theory has many sports manifestations. It is said that the number of people who claim to have witnessed Wilt Chamberlain’s 100-point game vastly exceeds the capacity of the arena in Hershey, Pennsylvania, where it happened. Resale prices of ticket stubs for baseball games where a no-hitter is thrown or another similarly improbable event happens are much higher than those for ordinary games of the same vintage. Such an adornment model of utility, in which the consumer seeks to maximize his collection of experienced rare events, can also be applied to such experiences as travel to exotic destinations or the race to be first to experience a trendy new restaurant. This kind of model goes beyond the mere taste-for-variety utility function of the Krugman (1980) type. The appeal of rarity, demonstrated by the appeal of the upset, is an area worth further exploration in the sports context.
